bibl.title: Henry Carlton v. William Cochrane. Order of Court
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory

text.body:
In the District Court for the Third Judicial District holding terms at Seattle W.T.
The Territory of Washington }No.5930 vs. Henry Carlton
The Defendant comes before me, upon Habeas Corpus
To the writ the Sheriff /// that Defendant is held by virtue of a commitment of which a copy is attached to the retur, whereby it appears the Deff. was convicted by and before N. Soderberg a Justice of the Peace "of the crime of Vagrancy by wilfully and unlawfully /// the business of gambling as a common ///"
Whereupon the Justice adjudged "that Defendant pay the costs taxed at Forty Dollars and be committed for thirteen days or until the sum be paid and should give a bond or recognizance in the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars for his good behavior for three months from April 14, 1888 the date of the judgement herein" "And whereas said Henry Carlton has failed to pay said costs and to give the bond, therefor the Keeper of the Jail is commanded to receive and keep the Defendant until he shall be thence discharged by due course of law"--
This commitment is dated April 24, 1888
The statute provides (Code Sec 1271) that gamesters are "vagrants" and (Sec 1272) that on complains made on aoth to a Justice of the Peace he shall issue a warrant for the arrest and examination of the person charged.
If it is made to appear to the Justice that the charge is true, he may "require a bond for his good behavior for those months thereafter" (Sec 1275)
The Justice is further required (Sec 1276) to make a record and file it with the clerk of the District Court specifying the nature and circumstances of the charge and if the bond be not fiven to commit the Defendant to jail until such security be formed/// or such vagrant be discharged according to law. *
A "gamester" is a "gambler" + being declared by our statute to be a vagrance as such required to give security for his good behavior" it is intended thereby that the bond given shall be a security that he will cause the /// practice of gambling - (sec. 1277)
The Defendant may have a trial by jury on the District Court on his own request-, and without such trial the District Court may revise such judgement of the Justice.
Sec. 1271 further provides that "the complaint warrant and arrest shall be governed by the
by the jurisdiction of Chapter 134" so far as it may be applicable, but by relevance thereto the afore stated /// are not essentially modified. Chapter 133 Sec. 1910 /// by provides that "in all cases" where a person is required to give security for his good behavior, the magistrate must order that such prison pay the costs and he "shall" stand committed until such costs are paid or he be otherwise legally discharged"
I may be contended perhaps that this section applies only to the matter mentioned in this chapter and has no relation to vagrancy, not included therein, and some reasons may be /// in support of such a contention --
I think whatever argument might be made however may be met by the provisions of section 2105 providing that a Justice may adjudge costs against any persons convicted before him or held to bail to keep the peace to be collected as in cases of fines, and in all such cases the Justice has power to commit a defendant to Jail until the judgement for fine and costs is satisfied (Sec. 1896)
I think it clear under laws that the Justice of the Peace in this case, did not meet his authority under the statute and that the commitment is lawful on its face --
My other reason is offered for the defendants discharge. I have not here considered /// criticism of language as no person should be discharged from an order of commitment on any more defect in the forms or words /// (sec. 678) but in such cases the court if the defect is material should hear the witnesses and investigate the matter /// - and is required to do so in all cases where such delect appears. This as I understand is however does not apply to a case where the commitment shows or its face that the magistrate had no jurisdiction in the matter.
In this case it is ordered and adjudged, that the Defendant Henry Carlton be remanded and this writ of Habeas Corpus be and is hereby discharged.
Dated April 28 1888
R.A. Jones Judge
No. 5930
In the matter of the application of Henry Carlton for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Order of Court
FILED APR 28 1888 W.E. Ledgerwood, Clerk.
